newsitem.title: AUSTRIA: PRESS DIGEST-CENTRAL AND EAST EUROPE-DEC 3.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST-CENTRAL AND EAST EUROPE-DEC 3.

text.p: AUSTRIA
DER STANDARD
- An EU agreement on monetary stability for European Monetary Union will force Austria to adopt a more flexible labour policy.
- Austrian retailers will earn 600 million schillings less from Christmas shopping this year than last due to the government's spending cuts.
- Bawag bank is planning to take over a qualified majority of insulation maker Economos by the end of the year.
- Investor Management-Trust-Holding is expects to pay out a 15 schilling dividend this year, as pre-tax profits will be 45 million schillings.
DIE PRESSE
- Bank rates are expected to fall even further as the first banks present plans to cut interest by up to half a percent. Meanwhile banking fees are going to be raised.
- The president of Austria's health insurance system Richard Leutner has demanded that industry should pay 700 million schillings to fund a new chip-card by 1998.
- Trade on the first weekend before Christmas with long shopping hours was better than expected.
- The Vienna stock exchange must prove itself as a high quality bourse if it is to survive the introduction of Europe's single currency euro.
KURIER
- Austria's salt monopoly Salinen AG is to be privatised in the near future. Investor Hannes Androsch group is seen to have the best chance of taking over the company.
- Cutlery maker Berndorf AG has presented plans to seek a listing at the Vienna stock exchange while it expects profits to rise by a third next year.
- Insurer Bundeslaender's premium earnings from life insurance are up seven percent.
WIRTSCHAFTSBLATT
- Austria will lose some 3.5 billion schillings worth of taxes on cigarettes this year as Austrians have been buying them in duty-free-shops across the country's border.
LATVIA
ALL NEWSPAPERS
- Finnish Prime Minister Paavo Lipponen paid a one-day visit to Latvia and signed an agreement with Latvian Interior Minister Dainis Turlais on the repatriation of illegal immigrants.

- Minister of Transport Vilis Krishtopans goes for a visit to Russia. He said that Latvia was ready to discuss repaying the debt of Latavio (3 million) on condition that the air company Air Baltic is given a licence to fly to Russia.
- Latvian Foreign Minister Valdis Birkavs did not leave for the OSCE summit in Lisbon on Sunday because his wife was bitten by a dog and was badly hurt.
DIENA
- The parliamentary parties of the ruling coalition do not have a united stand on the budget and it is difficult to forecast what the outcome will be.
NEATKARIGA RITA AVIZE

- The Latvian security police denied any link with Valdis Nikolajev, an alleged Latvian security agent, who, according to Russian television, tried to recruit a Russian navy officer in order to get information about Russian submarines.
BIZNES & BALTIYA

- The head of Latvia's delegations for talks with Lithuania, Maris Riekstinsh, has left for a one-day visit to Vilnius. He will meet new parliament chairman Vytautas Landsbergis and new foreign minister, Algirdas Saudargas.
- Riga district court declared the bankruptcy of the Visbija fuel retail company, which has debts of one million lats.
- The liquidators of Banka Baltija have started selling off some of the bank's property.
SM
- The OSCE high commissioner for human rights suggested that mentioning ethnic origin in Latvian passports should be optional not compulsory.
DIENAS BIZNESS
- Finnish company Vainiopaan Saha hopes to build a saw-mill near the eastern town of Aizkraukle by investing 27.1 million, of which nine million dollars will be received as a credit from the EBRD.
SLOVAKIA
NARODNA OBRODA - The proposed 1997 budget includes some 14 billion crowns for motorway construction and about five billion crowns for housing construction.

- The government will discuss a revised version of the controversial law on the protection of the Republic at its regular Tuesday session. The preliminary agenda of the session does not include any major economic items.
- Exports to the Czech Republic from Slovakia's sole tyre producer, Matador Puchov, totalled 1.3 billion crowns. Matador's major Czech customer is car maker Skoda.
HOSPODARSKE NOVINY - A delegation of the World Bank has begun a 10-day mission to the Slovak Republic, during which it will compile a report on the state of the Slovak economy.
- Slovakia's doctors said the proposed 1997 budget would have a negative impact on the standard of the country's health care system.
- The average monthly nominal wage in industry rose 13.9 percent year-on-year in the first nine months of this year and totalled 8,185 crowns as of September 30.
- Slovakia's tobacco production is expected to fall to about 1,500 tonnes this year, compared with some 3,600 tonnes in 1995.
- Slovak arms industry holding company DMD has taken a 400 million crown loan to support civilian production in heavy engineering company ZTS Martin.
- Roller bearing producer KLF-ZVL expects its turnover to total 1.6 billion crowns. The company exports about 70 percent of its production, which so far this year totalled some 1.1 billion crowns.
- The Slovak coal mining industry said it would need to raise prices by 10 percent to ensure further profitability of production.
SME - About 80 percent of workers in steel maker VSZ have already quit the official engineering and steel industry trade union OZ Kovo.
CZECH REPUBLIC
HOSPODARSKE NOVINY - A malignant tumor was removed from President Vaclav Havel's right lung during a 3.5 hour operation yesterday.

- The leadership of the Civic Democratic Alliance sent a new proposal for a coalition agreement to its coalition partners yesterday. In the proposed agreement, support for the state budget for 1997 was linked to the further liberalisation of rent and utilities prices, further privatisation and tax reforms. Other coalition members have agreed to discuss these issues but insist that they should not be related to the budget.

- Vladimir Stehlik, the general manager of Poldi Steel who has been in prison with his son Marek since last week, turned over all his holdings in the Kladno steelworks, worth 8.5 billion crowns, to Interior Minister Jan Ruml yesterday, according to Stehlik's legal representative, Milan Hulik. Stehlik turned over the documents so that he could not be accused of selling shares which did not belong to him. Stehlik is still the general manager of Poldi.

- Debts from the Slovak National Bank to the Czech National Bank arose legitimately during the division of federal property, especially during the division of the former Czechoslovak State Bank, according to a spokesman for the central Czech bank, Martin Svehla.

- The National Property Fund completed 81 privatisation projects, worth a total of 1.36 billion crowns, in October, according to a spokeswoman for the fund. the fund has privatised property worth a total of 880 billion crowns.

- The Minister of Trade and Industry, Vladimir Dlouhy, has denied that he prefers Russian gas, stating that all the variants for the diversification of the current natural gas supply will be considered.
- One month before the end of 1996, the government budget is once again in the red. The state budget deficit reached three billion crowns at the end of November.
- According to a recent public survey, Czechs find the fact that the number of foreigners, currently estimated at 200 thousand, increasingly negative.

- The Velke Popovice brewery is not planning to post any profits this year. Last year the brewery posted losses of 127 million crowns which decreased to seven million crowns in the first half of 1996.

MLADA FRONTA DNES - The Czech Statistic Bureau's last prognosis for GDP growth from the beginning of November is likely too optimistic, according to economists. The growth was expected to match last year's growth of 4.8 percent.
PRAVO - The city of Ostrava is issuing five-year Eurobonds worth 75 million marks (1.32 billion crowns), according to a representative from ING Barings.
- Daewoo Avia admitted that only 4900 lorries will be assembled this year instead of the originally planned 8000 lorries.
